title: Europe close: Stocks close higher as Greece asks for bailout
text:
89.93 +1.01 
LONDON (ShareCast) - European stocks ended in the black after Greece formally requested a three-year bailout from the European Stability Mechanism. The benchmark Stoxx Europe 600 index ended up 0.1%, France's CAC 40 closed 0.8% higher and Germany's DAX rose 0.7%. 
In the periphery, Spain's IBEX 35 closed up 0.8% while Italy's FTSE Mib rallied 2.7%. 
According to media reports late on Wednesday, Greek bank and capital controls will be extended to Friday. 
In a letter addressed to the ESM, the Greek Finance Ministry said Athens was committed to "a comprehensive set of reforms and measures to be implemented in the areas of fiscal sustainability, financial stability, and long-term economic growth." Athens said tax and pension reforms would be among the measures. 
On Tuesday, Eurozone leaders gave Athens a final deadline of Sunday to agree on new economic proposals for a bailout deal. 
If Greece fails to secure fresh funds, it will be unable to make its â‚¬3.5bn repayment to the European Central Bank on 20 July. 
"The ECB has made it clear that their support for Greek banks will end next week and the Eurogroup has 'a Grexit scenario prepared in detail' if a deal is not struck," said Angus Campbell, senior analyst at FxPro . 
On the corporate front, investors welcomed news that Barclays (LSE: BARC.L - news ) has ousted its chief executive Antony Jenkins, saying that "a change in leadership is required". Shares (Berlin: DI6.BE - news ) in the bank closed up 2%. 
Novartis (Xetra: 904278 - news ) rose 1% after the Food and Drug Administration approved the company's new heart failure drug. 
Shares in French catering group Sodexo ended a touch lower after it cuts its target for full-year 2015 revenue growth. 
In London, all eyes were on Chancellor George Osborne's Budget. Housebuilders took a hit after he revealed measures to cut tax relief on mortgage interest for buy-to-let landlords, along with a tightening up of non-domicile status. Banks got a boost from news that the bank levy will be reduced, while power generator Drax plummeted to an all-time low as Osborne scrapped the climate levy exemption. 
The latest Federal Open Market Committee minutes are due after the European close at 1900 BST.
